title: Kanlaon
meta_title: Kanlaon Volcano — Eruption History, 2024 Eruption & Facts | VolcanoAtlas
meta_description: Kanlaon is a 2,422 m active stratovolcano on Negros Island, Philippines. Explore its 33 eruptions, 2024 eruption, hazards, and the risks to nearby cities.

quick_answer.what: Kanlaon (also spelled Canlaon) is an active stratovolcano rising to 2,422 m (7,946 ft), the highest point on Negros Island in the central Philippines.
quick_answer.status: Active — most recently erupted in October 2024, with a VEI 3 eruption in June 2024. One of the most frequently active volcanoes in the Philippines.
quick_answer.famous_for: Persistent phreatic eruptions since 1866, the largest debris avalanche known in the Philippines (33 km runout), and the 2024 eruptions that forced major evacuations.
quick_answer.danger_level: High — over 100,000 people live within 15 km of the summit. Multiple cities including Canlaon City lie on the volcano's flanks.

hero.name: Kanlaon
hero.subtitle: The Highest Peak of Negros Island

key_facts_box.nearest_city: Canlaon City — on the volcano's eastern flank (~15 km from summit)
key_facts_box.summit_crater: 2 km-wide elongated northern caldera with crater lake; Lugud crater to south
key_facts_box.monitoring_agency: PHIVOLCS (Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology)

overview.content: Kanlaon (also spelled Canlaon) is an active stratovolcano forming the highest point on Negros Island in the central Philippines, rising to 2,422 m (7,946 ft) above sea level. It is one of the most frequently active volcanoes in the Philippine archipelago, with 33 recorded eruptions since 1866 — predominantly phreatic (steam-driven) explosions of small to moderate size that produce ashfall across surrounding agricultural communities. The massive andesitic volcano is covered with fissure-controlled pyroclastic cones and craters, many of which contain lakes. The summit features a 2 km-wide elongated northern caldera with a crater lake, and a smaller but higher active vent called Lugud crater to the south. Kanlaon is perhaps most geologically notable for having produced the largest debris avalanche known in the Philippines, a catastrophic flank collapse that traveled 33 km to the southwest. The volcano entered a period of heightened activity in 2024, with a VEI 3 eruption on June 3 — its most powerful in the modern record — followed by renewed activity beginning in October 2024 that continued into 2025. With over 100,000 people living within 15 km of the summit, including the city of Canlaon on its eastern flank, and the agriculturally vital sugar-producing lowlands of Negros surrounding the volcano, Kanlaon represents a significant volcanic hazard in one of the Philippines' most densely populated regions. The Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology (PHIVOLCS) maintains a monitoring network on the volcano, part of the Ring of Fire chain of volcanoes generated by the complex subduction tectonics of the Philippine archipelago.

geology_and_formation.content: Kanlaon lies within the Negros-Sulu Volcanic Arc, generated by the westward subduction of the Philippine Sea Plate beneath the Sunda Plate along a complex system of trenches and microplates that characterize Philippine tectonics. The volcano is constructed on continental crust exceeding 25 km in thickness, and its andesitic to basaltic-andesitic composition is typical of arc stratovolcanoes at subduction margins. The edifice is massive, with a broad base spanning much of central Negros Island. Its flanks are cut by numerous fissure-controlled features including pyroclastic cones and craters, many filled by lakes, indicating a complex history of vent migration and flank eruptions. The summit area hosts two notable features: a 2 km-wide elongated caldera on the northern summit, partially filled by a crater lake, and the higher Lugud crater to the south, which has been the source of most recent eruptive activity. The volcano's most dramatic geological feature is the enormous debris-avalanche deposit on the southwestern flank — the largest known in the Philippines — where a massive sector collapse sent an avalanche of rock and debris 33 km from the summit, creating a characteristically hummocky topography that is still visible in the landscape today. This collapse may have been triggered by a large eruption, earthquake, or edifice instability resulting from hydrothermal alteration of the summit rocks. The collapse scar has since been largely filled by subsequent volcanic growth.

eruption_history_overview.content: Kanlaon has produced 33 recorded eruptions since 1866, when systematic documentation began during the Spanish colonial period. The eruption record is characterized overwhelmingly by phreatic (steam-driven) explosions of small to moderate size, typically reaching VEI 1–2, that produce minor ashfall affecting nearby communities. These phreatic eruptions occur when groundwater or the crater lake is heated and pressurized by rising magma or volcanic gases, producing sudden explosive steam bursts. The 19th century saw relatively sporadic activity (eruptions in 1866, 1883, 1884, 1893, 1894, 1902, 1904, 1905), while the late 20th century was remarkably active with eruptions recorded nearly every year from 1969 to 1996. After a quieter period in the late 1990s, activity resumed in the 21st century with eruptions in 2002, 2003, 2005, 2006, 2015–2016, and 2017. The June 2024 eruption marked a significant escalation, reaching VEI 3 — the highest recorded explosivity at Kanlaon — followed by renewed activity in October 2024 that has continued into 2025.

subsections.title: The 1902 Eruption — Early 20th Century Activity
subsections.content: On January 31, 1902, Kanlaon produced a confirmed eruption reaching VEI 2, one of several eruptions during a period of heightened activity at the turn of the century. The eruption occurred during the same year as the catastrophic eruptions of Mount Pelée in Martinique and Santa Maria in Guatemala, which together killed over 30,000 people and drew global attention to volcanic hazards. Kanlaon's eruption was far smaller, consisting of phreatic explosions and moderate ashfall, but it established the volcano's pattern of frequent, moderate-scale activity that has continued throughout the 20th and 21st centuries.

subsections.title: The 1969–1996 Period — Decades of Persistent Activity
subsections.content: Between 1969 and 1996, Kanlaon erupted at least 16 times, averaging more than one eruption every two years and establishing it as one of the most persistently active volcanoes in the Philippines. The eruptions were predominantly phreatic, reaching VEI 1–2, with ashfall events affecting agricultural communities on the volcano's flanks. This sustained activity raised concerns about the possibility of escalation to larger magmatic eruptions and led to enhanced monitoring by PHIVOLCS. The most notable events occurred in 1969 (VEI 2), 1978 (VEI 2), 1985 (two eruptions), 1986 (VEI 2), and 1996 (VEI 2). The regularity of these eruptions made Kanlaon one of the best-studied volcanoes in the Visayas region.

subsections.title: The June 2024 Eruption — Kanlaon's Most Powerful Modern Event
subsections.content: On June 3, 2024, Kanlaon produced its most powerful eruption in the modern record, reaching VEI 3. The eruption generated a substantial eruption column, heavy ashfall across parts of Negros Island, and triggered PHIVOLCS to raise the alert level significantly. Thousands of residents within the permanent danger zone were evacuated. The VEI 3 classification marked a notable escalation from Kanlaon's typical VEI 1–2 phreatic explosions, suggesting that magmatic material may have played a greater role in the eruption. The ashfall disrupted agriculture, aviation, and daily life across the central Negros region. The eruption drew national and international attention to the volcano's hazard potential.

subsections.title: The October 2024–2025 Eruption — Ongoing Activity
subsections.content: Beginning on October 19, 2024, Kanlaon entered a new eruptive phase that continued into 2025, reaching VEI 2. This renewed activity came just four months after the VEI 3 eruption and included phreatic explosions, increased sulfur dioxide emissions, volcanic earthquakes, and intermittent ashfall. PHIVOLCS maintained elevated alert levels, and evacuation orders remained in effect for communities within the expanded danger zone. The rapid succession of eruptions in 2024–2025 raised concerns among volcanologists about potential further escalation and underscored the ongoing volcanic hazard to the region's population.

current_status_and_monitoring.content: As of early 2025, Kanlaon remains in a state of elevated volcanic unrest, with the eruption that began in October 2024 continuing. PHIVOLCS operates a comprehensive monitoring network including seismometers, tiltmeters, continuous GPS stations, sulfur dioxide flux measurements, and visual observation cameras. Alert levels have been maintained above baseline since the June 2024 VEI 3 eruption. Volcanic earthquakes, elevated sulfur dioxide emissions, and intermittent phreatic explosions have been recorded. The volcano's behavior in 2024–2025 represents its most sustained and intense activity period in the modern record, prompting ongoing evacuations and heightened preparedness measures. PHIVOLCS issues regular bulletins and coordinates with local government units on evacuation and hazard zone management.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content: Kanlaon's primary hazards include phreatic and phreatomagmatic explosions that produce ashfall, ballistic projectiles near the crater, and pyroclastic density currents on the upper slopes. The volcano's andesitic composition means that larger magmatic eruptions could produce pyroclastic flows, lava flows, and lahars — mudflows of volcanic debris carried by rainfall down the steep flanks into river valleys that drain toward populated lowlands. The enormous prehistoric debris avalanche that traveled 33 km to the southwest demonstrates that catastrophic flank collapse is within the volcano's capability. With over 100,000 people living within 15 km of the summit, including Canlaon City on the eastern flank and La Carlota, Bago, and other municipalities in the sugar-producing lowlands, the potential for casualties in a large eruption is significant. Lahar hazard is particularly concerning during typhoon season, when heavy rainfall can mobilize volcanic ash deposits into destructive mudflows. PHIVOLCS has defined permanent and extended danger zones around the summit, and evacuation plans are regularly tested and updated.

geography_and_physical_description.content: Kanlaon dominates the central portion of Negros Island, the fourth-largest island in the Philippines. The massive stratovolcano rises steeply from the surrounding lowlands to its 2,422 m summit, with lower slopes covered in tropical forest and the upper reaches transitioning to scrub and barren volcanic terrain. The summit area features the 2 km-wide elongated northern caldera, partially filled by a crater lake, and the Lugud crater at the volcano's highest point, which has been the primary vent for recent eruptions. Numerous fissure-controlled pyroclastic cones and craters dot the flanks, many containing lakes that add to the volcano's scenic landscape. The southwestern flank bears the hummocky topography of the enormous debris-avalanche deposit. Mount Kanlaon Natural Park protects the upper slopes, encompassing tropical and montane forests that harbor significant biodiversity including endemic bird species.

climate_and_global_impact.content: Kanlaon's eruptions have been too small to produce significant global climate effects. Even the VEI 3 eruption of June 2024, the largest on record, injected insufficient material into the stratosphere to affect hemispheric temperatures. The volcano's impact has been regional, with ashfall affecting agriculture across central Negros Island — particularly the sugar cane plantations that form the backbone of the local economy. Sulfur dioxide emissions during active periods affect local air quality and can damage crops. In the context of volcanic climate forcing, Kanlaon is comparable to other moderately active stratovolcanoes like Taal and Mayon, whose eruptions primarily affect local and regional environments.

cultural_significance.content: Kanlaon holds deep cultural significance in Visayan and Filipino tradition. In local mythology, Mount Kanlaon is associated with legends of a fierce dragon or serpent that dwells within the mountain, with eruptions attributed to the creature's anger. The name Kanlaon may derive from the Hiligaynon word for the legendary creature or from an ancient term meaning 'cauldron.' The volcano is central to the identity of Negros Island and its people. Mount Kanlaon Natural Park, established to protect the volcano's forests and biodiversity, is a popular destination for Filipino mountaineers and nature enthusiasts. The mountain's prominence has made it a symbol of Negros Occidental province, appearing in local government seals and cultural imagery. The sugar industry that flourishes on the fertile volcanic soils of Kanlaon's lower slopes has shaped the economic and social history of Negros for centuries.

visiting_and_tourism.content: Mount Kanlaon Natural Park is a popular mountaineering destination in the Philippines, with established trails ascending the volcano from both the Negros Occidental (western) and Negros Oriental (eastern) sides. The standard ascent takes 2–3 days with overnight camping. The volcano's tropical and montane forests, crater lakes, and summit views attract thousands of climbers annually. However, access to the summit area is restricted or prohibited during periods of volcanic unrest — as has been the case since mid-2024. Climbers must register with the park office, arrange required guides, and check the current PHIVOLCS alert level. Canlaon City on the eastern flank serves as a common base for ascents. The surrounding agricultural landscapes of sugar cane and tropical fruit offer additional cultural tourism opportunities.

nearby_volcanoes.content: Negros Island also hosts Cuernos de Negros, a dormant volcanic complex on the southeastern portion of the island. Across the Tañon Strait, the island of Cebu has no active volcanoes, but the broader central Philippines is home to Taal on Luzon, one of the most dangerous volcanoes in the Philippines. To the south, Mayon in the Bicol region is the country's most active and symmetrical stratovolcano. In the broader Philippine volcanic arc, Mount Pinatubo produced the largest eruption of the 20th century in 1991.

etymology.content: The name Kanlaon (also commonly spelled Canlaon) has uncertain origins. It may derive from a Hiligaynon or Cebuano term for a mythological creature said to inhabit the mountain, or from a local word meaning 'cauldron' — a reference to the summit craters. The alternative English spelling 'Canlaon' reflects the Spanish colonial orthography, while 'Kanlaon' follows modern Filipino spelling conventions. The city at the volcano's base, Canlaon City, preserves the older Spanish-influenced spelling.

facts: Kanlaon has produced 33 recorded eruptions since 1866, making it one of the most frequently active volcanoes in the Philippines.
The volcano generated the largest debris avalanche known in the Philippines, with a runout distance of 33 km to the southwest.
The June 2024 eruption reached VEI 3, the most powerful eruption in Kanlaon's modern record and a significant escalation from its typical phreatic events.
Between 1969 and 1996, Kanlaon erupted at least 16 times — averaging more than one eruption every two years.
Over 100,000 people live within 15 km of Kanlaon's summit, including the city of Canlaon on the eastern flank.
The summit features both a 2 km-wide caldera with a crater lake and the higher Lugud crater, the primary active vent.
Negros Island's sugar cane industry, which historically dominated the Philippine sugar market, depends on the fertile volcanic soils of Kanlaon's lower slopes.
Kanlaon's flanks are dotted with numerous fissure-controlled pyroclastic cones and crater lakes, indicating a complex history of vent migration.
In local Visayan mythology, the volcano is associated with a legendary dragon or serpent that causes eruptions when angered.
Mount Kanlaon Natural Park protects the volcano's tropical and montane forests, which harbor endemic bird species found nowhere else in the world.

faqs.question: Is Kanlaon an active volcano?
faqs.answer: Yes, Kanlaon is classified as an active volcano by PHIVOLCS and is one of the most frequently active volcanoes in the Philippines. It has erupted 33 times since 1866, with the most recent activity occurring in 2024–2025. The June 2024 eruption reached VEI 3, the strongest in the modern record, and renewed activity beginning October 2024 has continued into 2025. PHIVOLCS continuously monitors the volcano with seismometers, gas sensors, and deformation instruments.

faqs.question: When did Kanlaon last erupt?
faqs.answer: Kanlaon's most recent eruptive activity began on October 19, 2024, and has continued into 2025. This followed the larger VEI 3 eruption on June 3, 2024, which was the most powerful eruption in Kanlaon's modern record. The rapid succession of eruptions in 2024–2025 has kept alert levels elevated and necessitated ongoing evacuations of communities within the expanded danger zone.

faqs.question: How tall is Kanlaon?
faqs.answer: Kanlaon stands 2,422 m (7,946 ft) above sea level, making it the highest point on Negros Island, the fourth-largest island in the Philippines. It is slightly shorter than Mayon volcano (2,462 m) in the Bicol region but significantly taller than Taal volcano (311 m) south of Manila. The summit is composed of the elongated northern caldera and the higher Lugud crater, the primary active vent.

faqs.question: What type of volcano is Kanlaon?
faqs.answer: Kanlaon is a stratovolcano, also known as a composite volcano, built up of alternating layers of lava flows, ash, and pyroclastic material. Its andesitic to basaltic-andesitic composition is typical of stratovolcanoes at subduction zone margins. The massive edifice is further decorated with numerous fissure-controlled pyroclastic cones and craters on its flanks. The summit hosts both a caldera with a crater lake and the active Lugud crater.

faqs.question: Is it safe to climb Kanlaon?
faqs.answer: Mount Kanlaon Natural Park is normally a popular mountaineering destination, with established trails and a typical 2–3 day ascent. However, access to the summit area is restricted or prohibited during periods of volcanic unrest. Since mid-2024, the volcano has been under elevated alert levels due to VEI 3 and VEI 2 eruptions, and climbing has been prohibited within the expanded danger zone. Climbers should always check the current PHIVOLCS alert level and register with park authorities before any ascent.

faqs.question: Why is Kanlaon dangerous?
faqs.answer: Kanlaon poses significant hazards because over 100,000 people live within 15 km of its summit, including Canlaon City. The volcano produces phreatic explosions, ashfall, and during larger eruptions, potential pyroclastic flows and lahars. The lahar threat is particularly concerning during the Philippines' typhoon season, when heavy rainfall can mobilize ash into destructive mudflows. Additionally, the prehistoric debris avalanche that traveled 33 km demonstrates that catastrophic flank collapse is within the volcano's capability.

faqs.question: Where is Kanlaon located?
faqs.answer: Kanlaon is located in the central portion of Negros Island in the Visayas region of the Philippines, at coordinates 10.410°N, 123.130°E. The volcano straddles the border between Negros Occidental and Negros Oriental provinces. Canlaon City sits on the eastern flank, while several municipalities including La Carlota and Bago lie on the western lowlands. The nearest major city is Bacolod, the Negros Occidental capital, approximately 50 km to the northwest.
